body.p: A landing process refers to the steps and procedures that are followed by an aircraft and its crew to safely bring the aircraft down from flight to the runway. It is a crucial part of the flight and involves multiple stages, including descent, approach, flare, and touch down.

section.title: Regular Landing Procedure
section.p: The normal landing procedure for a Boeing 747 typically involves several stages:

ol.li: Descent: The pilot will initiate the descent to the landing runway by reducing altitude and airspeed. This may be done by reducing engine thrust and deploying the landing gear.

Approach: During the approach, the pilot will line up the aircraft with the runway and adjust the airspeed and altitude to match the recommended approach profile. The pilot will also configure the aircraft by extending the flaps and slats, which increase the lift and drag of the wings to allow for a slower approach speed.
Flare: As the aircraft nears the runway, the pilot will "flare" the aircraft by pulling back on the control column to reduce the rate of descent and touch down more gently.
Touchdown: The wheels of the aircraft will touch down on the runway, and the pilot will use the brakes to bring the aircraft to a complete stop on the runway.

section.title: Post Landing Procedure
section.p: Once the aircraft has landed, the pilot will typically perform several post-landing procedures, including:

ol.li: Taxiing: The pilot will taxi the aircraft to the designated parking area on the airport's ramp using the aircraft's nose wheel steering and brakes.
Shutdown: The pilot will shut down the engines and perform other checks such as setting the parking brakes and shutting off electrical systems.
Secure the aircraft: The pilot will ensure that all doors are secure, the flight deck is secured, and all passengers have safely disembarked the aircraft.
File a flight plan: The pilot will file a flight plan that summarizes the flight's details, including the route, flight time, and fuel consumption.
Debriefing: The pilot may have a debriefing with the rest of the flight crew to discuss any issues or incidents that occurred during the flight.
Maintenance check: The aircraft may require maintenance checks or inspections before it is cleared for its next flight.

section.title: Engine Failure Procedure
section.p: In the event of an engine failure on an airplane, the procedure for a safe landing will involve the following steps:

ol.li: Maintaining control: The pilot will adjust the aircraft's speed, altitude, and attitude to counteract any yaw or roll that may result from the engine failure.

Glide path: The pilot will try to establish a glide path that allows the aircraft to maintain altitude as much as possible and reach the nearest suitable landing site. The pilot will adjust the aircraft's speed, angle, and configuration to optimize the glide distance and reach a safe landing spot.

Engine failure checklist: The pilot will follow the engine failure checklist, which includes items such as reducing the thrust on the operating engine, extending the landing gear, and configuring the flaps for landing.
Landing gear: The pilot will lower the landing gear to provide a stable platform for landing.
Flaps: The pilot will extend the flaps to provide additional lift and to slow the aircraft down for landing.
Final approach: The pilot will maneuver the aircraft into a stable approach for landing, aiming for the centerline of the runway.
Touchdown: The pilot will aim for a smooth touchdown on the runway, using the nosewheel first to absorb the initial impact.
Evacuation: If necessary, the pilot will initiate an emergency evacuation of the aircraft following a safe landing.

section.title: Landing on Water
section.p: Landing on water refers to the process of bringing an aircraft down to the surface of a body of water, either intentionally in the case of a water landing or ditching, or unintentionally in the case of a crash.

A water landing or ditching is a controlled descent onto the surface of water, usually carried out in emergency situations when the pilot is unable to reach a suitable landing runway. In these cases, the pilot will aim to land the aircraft as smoothly as possible to minimize the risk of damage or injury to the aircraft and its occupants.
On the other hand, a crash into water is an uncontrolled descent into the water and usually results in significant damage to the aircraft and potentially serious injury or death to the occupants.

Regardless of the reason, landing on water is considered to be a high-risk situation, and all aircraft are designed with specific safety features to help minimize the risk to the occupants in the event of a water landing or ditching. These may include flotation devices, life rafts, and emergency exits designed to allow occupants to quickly evacuate the aircraft after it comes to a stop on the water.
